bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to George Miller Sternberg, August 1, 1896

div1.p: Reed describes his arrival in Key West and his observation of several smallpox cases in the hospital there. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to George Miller Sternberg, August 1, 1896
div1.opener:
Major Walter Reed
Key West, Fla.
August 1, '96
My dear Doctor:
div1.p:
Upon my
arrival, Tuesday afternoon,
I found Dr. Kean awaiting
me. Who kindly took me
to meet Dr. Porter, State
Health Officer, and Dr. White
of the Marine Hospital
Service. With the latter,
I visited the Small - Pox
Camp at 6 a.m. Wednesday
morning & was given every
opportunity to examine
cases. To my surprise,
I found only 2 cases which
appeared to be suitable
for study - both cases of good
discreet S. Pox; one at the 7th
day of eruption and the other
at the 4th day. I have
examined the blood of 2
others, older cases, with
negative results. Both
of the discreet cases give
the same bodies as seen
in monkey's blood. 8th
day of one cases gave
a number, but on the 9th
day I could find none.
On 6th & 7th days (today) I
have found some few,
with hard work in the other case - I will
continue tomorrow & Monday
on these two cases & after that
study blood of several Con-
valescents. I will leave
on Saturday Wednesday next,
for Washington.

Weather has been & is
extremely hot. This climate,
at first, certainly robs
one of all energy to work.
The Epidemic appears
to be over. With kind
regards.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Walter Reed. To Gen. Sternberg
72
